You manage a large dataset that logs sensor readings every second for multiple devices across different locations. The table contains columns: device_id, location, timestamp, and reading_value. You are tasked with retrieving the 3rd highest sensor reading for each location in the last 24 hours.

Which query would efficiently retrieve the required data?

questionOptions.body:
SELECT location, MAX(reading_value) 
FROM sensor_readings 
WHERE timestamp >= NOW() - INTERVAL 1 DAY 
GROUP BY location;

SELECT location, reading_value 
FROM sensor_readings s1 
WHERE 2 = (SELECT COUNT(DISTINCT s2.reading_value) 
           FROM sensor_readings s2 
           WHERE s2.reading_value > s1.reading_value AND s2.location = s1.location
             AND s2.timestamp >= NOW() - INTERVAL 1 DAY)
ORDER BY location;

SELECT location, reading_value 
FROM sensor_readings s1 
WHERE reading_value = (SELECT MIN(s2.reading_value) 
                       FROM (SELECT DISTINCT reading_value 
                             FROM sensor_readings 
                             WHERE location = s1.location AND timestamp >= NOW() - INTERVAL 1 DAY 
                             ORDER BY reading_value DESC 
                             LIMIT 2, 1) s2)
ORDER BY location;

WITH RankedReadings AS (
  SELECT location, reading_value, 
         ROW_NUMBER() OVER (PARTITION BY location ORDER BY reading_value DESC) AS rank 
  FROM sensor_readings 
  WHERE timestamp >= NOW() - INTERVAL 1 DAY
)
SELECT location, reading_value 
FROM RankedReadings 
WHERE rank = 3;

Write a query that retrieves all customers along with their total order amount and total payment amount, including customers who have never placed an order or made a payment.

questionOptions.body:
SELECT C.CustomerID, C.Name, 
       COALESCE(SUM(O.Amount), 0) AS TotalOrderAmount, 
       COALESCE(SUM(P.PaymentAmount), 0) AS TotalPaymentAmount
FROM Customers C  
LEFT JOIN Orders O ON C.CustomerID = O.CustomerID  
LEFT JOIN Payments P ON C.CustomerID = P.CustomerID  
GROUP BY C.CustomerID, C.Name;

SELECT C.CustomerID, C.Name, 
       SUM(O.Amount) AS TotalOrderAmount, 
       SUM(P.PaymentAmount) AS TotalPaymentAmount
FROM Customers C  
INNER JOIN Orders O ON C.CustomerID = O.CustomerID  
INNER JOIN Payments P ON C.CustomerID = P.CustomerID  
GROUP BY C.CustomerID, C.Name;

SELECT C.CustomerID, C.Name, 
       SUM(O.Amount) AS TotalOrderAmount, 
       SUM(P.PaymentAmount) AS TotalPaymentAmount
FROM Customers C  
RIGHT JOIN Orders O ON C.CustomerID = O.CustomerID  
RIGHT JOIN Payments P ON C.CustomerID = P.CustomerID  
GROUP BY C.CustomerID, C.Name;

SELECT C.CustomerID, C.Name, 
       SUM(O.Amount) AS TotalOrderAmount, 
       SUM(P.PaymentAmount) AS TotalPaymentAmount
FROM Customers C  
FULL JOIN Orders O ON C.CustomerID = O.CustomerID

SELECT E.EmpID, E.Name, M.Name AS ManagerName, P.ProjectName

LEFT JOIN Projects P ON E.EmpID = P.EmpID;

Which of the following strategies helps in avoiding deadlock in an operating system?
What is the purpose of the "fork" system call in UNIX-based operating systems?

questionOptions.body: To create a new process by duplicating the calling process

questionContent.body: Which of the following is the main function of an operating system?

questionOptions.body: To manage hardware resources and provide services to application software

questionContent.body: Which of the following is the key difference between preemptive and non-preemptive scheduling?

questionOptions.body: In preemptive scheduling, the OS can interrupt a running process. In non-preemptive, it cannot.
Preemptive scheduling always runs in a round-robin fashion.
Non-preemptive scheduling runs the highest priority process first.
Preemptive scheduling is suitable only for batch processing systems.

questionContent.body: Which of the following is used for memory management in operating systems?
Which of the following best describes a system call in an operating system?

questionOptions.body: A function called from user-space programs to interact with hardware directly
A mechanism for a process to request services from the kernel

questionContent.body: Which of the following describes a process in an operating system?

questionOptions.body: A series of instructions that can be executed

questionContent.body: Which of the following statements is TRUE regarding transactions in SQL?

questionOptions.body: A transaction must always be committed before rollback is possible
Savepoints allow selective rollback within a transaction
A rollback can undo a committed transaction
COMMIT is used to temporarily store transaction changes

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Think about how savepoints help in breaking down transactions into smaller reversible parts.

questionContent.body: What happens when a system crash occurs before a COMMIT statement is executed?

questionOptions.body: The transaction is lost and must be restarted
The database automatically rolls back uncommitted changes
The changes remain permanently in the database

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: If a transaction isn’t committed, SQL won’t permanently save it.

questionContent.body: When using a SAVEPOINT, which of the following statements is FALSE?

questionOptions.body: Multiple savepoints can exist within a single transaction
Rolling back to a savepoint removes all savepoints created after it
A savepoint automatically commits all previous changes

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Savepoints allow rollback within a transaction, but they don’t commit changes automatically.

questionContent.body: If two transactions execute simultaneously and one transaction reads uncommitted changes from another, what is this issue called?

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: A Dirty Read occurs when a transaction reads data that another transaction has modified but not committed.

questionContent.body: What does the Isolation property in ACID help prevent?

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Isolation ensures that transactions execute independently and do not affect each other’s execution.

questionContent.body: A transaction transfers ₹100 from Account A to Account B. What ACID property ensures that neither account loses or gains extra money in case of failure?

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Consistency ensures that the total sum before and after the transaction remains unchanged.

questionContent.body: Which of the following violates the Isolation property in a database transaction?

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Phantom Read occurs when new records appear in a query’s result set due to another transaction's insert operation.

questionContent.body: If a power failure occurs during a transaction, which ACID property ensures the database remains consistent after recovery?

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Durability ensures that committed transactions remain in the database even after failures.

questionContent.body: Which property ensures that a transaction is either fully completed or fully rolled back?

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Atomicity ensures that a transaction is "all or nothing." If any part fails, the entire transaction is rolled back.

questionContent.body: What happens if a transaction violates the ACID properties?

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: If ACID properties are not maintained, data integrity and consistency may be compromised.

questionContent.body: What does the Consistency property in ACID ensure?

questionOptions.body: The database remains in a valid state before and after a transaction

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Consistency ensures that only valid data is written to the database,maintaining integrity.

questionContent.body: Which of the following properties ensures that once a transaction is committed, it remains so even in the case of a system crash?

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Durability ensures that committed transactions are permanently stored and not lost due to failures.

questionContent.body: Which type of lock allows multiple transactions to read but prevents write operations?

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: A Shared Lock allows multiple transactions to read the data but prevents modifications.

questionContent.body: A transaction holds a lock and waits for another transaction to release its lock, while the second transaction is also waiting for the first to release its lock. What is this scenario called?

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: A Deadlock occurs when two or more transactions are waiting for each other to release locks.

questionContent.body: Which isolation level provides the highest level of isolation but reduces concurrency?

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Serializable ensures complete isolation, but it can lead to performance bottlenecks.

questionContent.body: Which of the following is NOT a technique to handle deadlocks?

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Deadlock Execution is not a valid term. The correct approaches are detection, prevention, and avoidance.

questionContent.body: In a hash table, which of the following is NOT a method for handling collisions?
Which of the following data structures is used in the implementation of the Prim's Minimum Spanning Tree (MST) algorithm?

solution.name: DSA
solution.details: • Binary Heap

questionContent.body: In a priority queue implemented with a binary heap, which operation has a time complexity of O(log n)?
Which of the following algorithms is NOT a greedy algorithm?
In which case does the worst-case time complexity of QuickSort become O(n^2)?

questionOptions.body: When the pivot is always the first or last element
When the pivot is always the middle element

questionContent.body: Which of the following is the correct worst-case time complexity of an in-order traversal of a binary tree?
What is the space complexity of the Merge Sort algorithm?
What is the worst-case time complexity of accessing an element in a hash table with separate chaining, assuming all elements hash to the same bucket?
Which of the following graph traversal algorithms can be used to find the shortest path in an unweighted graph?

questionOptions.body: There is a path from any vertex to every other vertex in the graph
All edges in the graph are bidirectional
All vertices have an equal number of incoming and outgoing edges

questionContent.body: What is the time complexity of finding the shortest path between two nodes in an unweighted graph using BFS?
What is the best-case time complexity of the Insertion Sort algorithm?
Which of the following is the correct representation of a non-binary tree?

questionOptions.body: Each node can have any number of children
Each node can have at most two children
Each node can only have one parent

questionContent.body: What is the time complexity of checking if a graph is bipartite using BFS or DFS?
Which data structure is used in implementing the Bellman-Ford algorithm?
What is the worst-case time complexity of the Floyd-Warshall algorithm for finding the shortest paths between all pairs of vertices in a graph?
Which of the following sorting algorithms is not stable?
What is the primary advantage of using a Trie over a hash table for storing strings?

questionOptions.body: Tries support prefix searches efficiently
Tries have better space complexity

questionContent.body: In a red-black tree, which of the following is a property that must hold true after every insertion?

questionOptions.body: The tree must remain balanced with each insertion
The root node must always be black.
Every path from a node to its descendant leaves must have the same number of black nodes.

questionContent.body: In the context of the A algorithm, what is the function used to estimate the cost to reach the goal from a given node?
In which deadlock handling technique are transactions rolled back when a deadlock is detected?

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Deadlock Detection uses wait-for graphs to identify deadlocks and roll back transactions

questionContent.body: Which locking mechanism prevents transactions from indefinitely waiting for resources?

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Timeouts can be used to abort transactions that wait too long, preventing indefinite waits.

questionContent.body: What is the main disadvantage of using strict two-phase locking (Strict 2PL)?

questionOptions.body: It allows transactions to release locks early

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Strict 2PL holds exclusive locks until commit, which can cause deadlocks but ensures strict serializability.

questionContent.body: What is the primary role of the CPU scheduler in an operating system?

questionOptions.body: To decide which process will run next

questionContent.body: Which of the following is true about a page table in a virtual memory system?

questionOptions.body: It maps virtual addresses to physical addresses
It stores data from disk to be loaded into memory
It is used to handle system calls
It stores the execution history of processes

questionContent.body: Which of the following scheduling algorithms has the possibility of causing starvation?
What is the main purpose of concurrency control in DBMS?

questionOptions.body: To increase the execution time of transactions
To allow multiple transactions to execute simultaneously without interference
To ensure a single transaction executes at a time

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Concurrency control ensures transactions execute correctly when running concurrently.

questionContent.body: In two-phase locking (2PL), which phase allows a transaction to acquire locks but not release them?

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: In the Growing Phase of 2PL, a transaction can acquire locks but not release them.

questionContent.body: A transaction consists of three operations: INSERT, UPDATE, and DELETE. A rollback is issued after the UPDATE. What will happen?

questionOptions.body: The INSERT and UPDATE are undone, but DELETE remains
The rollback will fail since DELETE was the last operation

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Rollback reverts to the last committed state or a savepoint, affecting only what happened after that point.

questionContent.body: Which isolation level allows transactions to read uncommitted changes made by other transactions?

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Uncommitted" means it allows reading unconfirmed changes from other transactions.

questionContent.body: What is starvation in DBMS concurrency control?

questionOptions.body: When a transaction is stuck in a loop
When a transaction is waiting indefinitely for a resource due to high-priority transactions acquiring locks first
When the system crashes due to multiple deadlocks
When all transactions execute at the same time

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Starvation happens when lower-priority transactions keep getting delayed due to higher-priority transactions acquiring locks first.

questionContent.body: What happens when two transactions hold locks on separate data items and each wants to acquire a lock on the other’s data item?

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: This is a classic example of a Deadlock, where each transaction waits indefinitely for the other to release a lock.

questionContent.body: What is the best way to avoid starvation in locking mechanisms?

questionOptions.body: Use a fair locking policy such as First Come First Serve (FCFS)

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: A fair locking policy ensures that transactions get a fair chance to acquire locks and execute in order.

questionContent.body: What is a possible solution to prevent deadlocks in DBMS?

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Wait-Die and Wound-Wait are common deadlock prevention techniques based on timestamps.

questionContent.body: What happens when a transaction tries to modify data that is already locked with a shared lock?

questionOptions.body: The transaction is blocked until the shared lock is released

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: A Shared Lock prevents modifications until it is released

questionContent.body: What type of lock prevents both read and write operations on a data item?

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: An Exclusive Lock ensures that no other transaction can read or modify the locked data.

questionContent.body: Which type of lock is used to indicate that a transaction intends to acquire a shared or exclusive lock later?

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Intent Locks are used to signal that a transaction will later request a Shared or Exclusive Lock.
